description: From around 1620–1630 from Medieval Latin genūflectō (“I bend the knee”) equivalent to the Latin genū (“knee”) + flectō (“to bend”).

verbs.description: genuflect (third-person singular simple present genuflects, present participle genuflecting, simple past and past participle genuflected)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To bend the knee, as in servitude.
(intransitive) To briefly enter a position that touches one knee to the ground in a manner that is typically associated with formal homage or religious worship.
examples: At high Mass the deacon and subdeacon stand on either side, genuflect too, and answer.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To behave in a servile manner; to grovel.
